comments.commentBody: Mary Scott--Wow!  You said it all, very eloquently.  Thank you.

The point of no return is when all options fail-I don't believe we are there..................yet. American history has had periods very similar to this.
. The path that the GOP has taken is to control by lies, no one can do that forever. Since they live by the big lie(s)-results of their lies will eventually show. But your points are well made, we are, dangerously close to becoming
a divided country, literally.
All correct.  Especially the comment about the press.  With honest, responsible reporting, we wouldn't be in this mess.

Our political system is breaking down just as rapidly as the "European supranational state system" you reference. It's taken thirty years to get here, but the speed of decline in the last few years is breathtaking. In two weeks, we may elect a president who has not one significant qualification to that office and whose entire campaign is based on one lie after another.

He is the standard bearer of a party that has renounced every good governance principle we value and has sabotaged every decent effort our president has made to move us forward. He is bankrolled by a bunch of billionaires who expect a return on their investment, thanks to a failing Supreme Court where ideologues dominate. He is supported by sleazy characters like Karl Rove who value political power over all else. He is enabled by a press/media that now seems to value sensation over truth telling.

If Mitt Romney wins this election, the decline will be complete as will our ability to "control our destiny." We will have reached the point of no return.

John, If you think houses aren't broken into, I suggest you take a look at statistics.  Even in the decent rural area I live in, burglaries are fairly common.  Perhaps as a guy, you react differently to the prospect of an intruder in your home than a woman or older person does.

Ms. Muppet, if your girlfriend's drunk crazy husband (who has been chasing you in his car) is in your garage, threatening you, that is quite different than a placid Jehovah's witness at your front door ringing the doorbell.

CLEARLY, Mr. Fredenberg was angry and drunk and meaning to "get even" with Mr. Harper, for stealing his wife away.

There was a clear and present threat here.
So I shoot you dead in MY yard because I am afraid of you for being nuts and dangerous and THAT makes sense to you?

They could have planned the entire thing. The wife needs to go help the boyfriend...they drive around the block, knowing the husband is watching them. His anger and frustration build. The wife drops off the boyfriend, knowing a confrontation will ensue, and knowing that the boyfriend is going to get his gun.
I always say... "When in Montana -- wear a gun to all Barbecues."

Susan, I hardly think a jealous, drunken cuckolded husband -- who was following Mr. Harper around in his CAR, spoiling for a fight -- is the equivalent of GIRL SCOUTS selling cookies at the front door.

Clearly these two men were headed for a fight of some kind over Mrs. Fredenberg and it just all came to a head that evening.

It is a tragedy, but it is what happens when drunk, jealousy crazy men try to start fights with their wife's lovers.

A lot of country western song possibilities here. But no crime.
Yeah, really.  What is that photo of her and the kid doing in the paper.  If anyone is responsible for her husband's death, it's her.

As a fellow liberal, I must say that this is a refreshingly non-hypocritical opinion, and I am honestly not being sarcastic. My only concern here though is that in an effort to guarantee the rights of a homeowner to defend themselves, we might be over-correcting and denying the rights of the person allegedly committing the offense by entering the house. Even if entering the house is a crime, I don't believe it is always one that deserves death.

However, I am not not going to say anything as silly as saying that the homeowner should have attempted to shoot the offender in a non-lethal location. That sort of thing might work in the movies, but in practice, if you're going to use a gun you should shoot to kill.

So what does that leave us with? It leaves us with no easy answer. Both sides of the argument have good points to make, and the reality of how guns work limit the number of most likely outcomes. If anything, I would argue that the only thing that can be said is that laws that make a clear determination--one way or another--are pretty much the only wrong answer. A law which always prohibits gun use in situations like these would be wrong, just as a law is that always allows it. The only solution I can urge is to remove laws that rigidly demand an action, and instead let a jury of peers make a decision based on the nuances of the case.
Hope you don't own a gun.

Maria,

It is apparently not that easy to shoot someone where you want to. If someone aims for the legs, they could easily miss altogether and then it's too late, they're being beaten to death.

The law does not say "at your front door".

It says "inside your HOME".

Mr. Fredenberg entered Mr. Harper's HOME -- INSIDE, without permission. He was not knocking at the front door.

Also, since the two were fighting over Mrs. Fredenberg, there was reason on both parties behalf to believe there was about to be a violent altercation.

"there is a lot of paper work to fill out and questions to answer"

I am seriously trying not to laugh when I read comments about girl scouts, Jehovah witnesses and trick and treaters being shot. But your comment was just the last straw. I am laughing as I am typing this. Thank you for brightening my day.
Don't worry, in Montana it's not as big of a deal. They're not into paperwork like us West Coasters.

Shooting someone, even as a last resort in self defense,  is a really a big deal. If nothing else there is a lot of paper work to fill out and questions to answer. That means a lot of long lasting emotion and wasted time. If I were threatened and had the time,  I would be out of the house and over the back fence in preference to pulling the trigger.
Wonder if the wife and her neighbor had seen and gotten ideas from the movie "The Postman Always Rings Twice" with Lana Turner and John Garfield?
It's always easier to claim that someone is physically abusive once he's dead and can't sue for libel.  Any court or police records?

Something sounds odd here, beyond the gun control debate. The article suggests that the wife knew her husband could be physically abusive.  She goes to see a man she has somesort of a relationship with, and hangs up on her husband when he asks where she is. She certainly knew how to press the husband's buttons. Sounds like a way of life that should not steer a national debate on gun control,,,maybe training on how to avoid manipulative personalities for spouses and extramarital friends?

How can you convince an animal to protect another? Communists are not human. The publicity on this case may work, but imagine the destruction brought about by the commies through out the years. Nothing, including humanity, is intact. Good luck, guys.

But you do have time to comment on this article, in order to inform the world that the children whose deaths are reported here were just stupid.  I'd hate to think what you would be like if you WERE heartless.
We have enough regulations, we don't need anymore.  This is completely ridiculous.

I remember watching C-Span sometime within the last year and Dick Durbin was on the Senate floor introducing a bill signed by many more Senators trying to get these "energy" drinks regulated or at least labeled and brought under the regulation of the government on some level. His bill was shot down by an overwhelming majority of corporatist Senators who claimed that regulation was overreach by the evil government. So you are on your own people. Teach your children well...
It's not over. Talk to the democrats to know, get them out to vote! Vote Democrats vote!

For some reason my first link, to the Washington Post article, doesn't work.

Here it is again:

http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/wp/2012/10/23/how-to-mani...

(If that fails it's the 10/23/2012 11:29 am article, "How to swing the prediction markets and boost Mitt Romney's fortunes." [But please don't! Thanks! MG])

"A lead" in "a poll"?

You don't read this site much, do you?
Can't stand the Rove.

i think intrade would be like vegas drop a wad of money on one side has to change the odds so it would be easy to manipulate.maybe what is happening to some of the polls out there.politics is dirty.just hope obama s team can counter they are pros i but rove is filthy.beat him in 2012 it maysend him into early retirement.having spent hundreds of millions of other people money
Based upon the electoral college and state-by-state comparisons. Did you actually read the article? Nate explained that in it.

That's a 1 in 3 chance of Romney winning, vs 2 in 3 for Obama.  Ask yourself, how much would I bet that Obama would win given those odds.  Most people wouldn't bet much either way.  Thus, the race is close.
That IS tight.
If the race is so tight, Why does this site have Romney at a 29% chance of winning?
Will we?  It's not 47.6-45.7 in two weeks that concerns me, rather its 5-4 in late December.

Mike D, I am well aware that the electoral college is all that matters, and I am well aware about the popular/electoral split in 2000. In fact, I mentioned in my original post the possibility of a popular/electoral split and that I doubt it would occur once the popular vote differences between the candidates exceed about 0.5%. Actually, I might amend this up to, say, 1%, but after that, the electoral college is unlikely to out-of-whack with the popular vote. Mr. Silver has made this point himself--i.e. if it's not a very close electon in the popular vote, then there won't be a popular/electoral split.

Moreover, I believe that the national polls are trending strongly toward Romney in recent days. Just take a look at the three most recent national polls, which are listed on Real Clear Politics.

I recommend that all of you check out the individual polls and make up your own minds about things, rather than rely on aggregated information on 538 or anywhere else. That being said, I think that--only because of Ohio and Romney's "Let Detroit Go Bankrupt" editorial--Obama has a chance (maybe 50-50) of winning this election.
